title: How to start with technical writing - Quora

response.answer_text: Nowadays it’s extremely easy to get started building up a useful resumé, even if you have no prior experience. It’s never been important to have a degree in technical communications, or even a certificate of any kind. In fact, a college degree in any other field would probably impress potential employers more. During my technical writing career, I saw physicists, computer scientists, midwives, and any number of others getting hired and doing great work as technical writers. An easy way to start racking up resumé credit is go head over to github.com, pick a project or two, and start contributing to the documentation. Contribute a lot! But make sure people like your work. It’s no good to contribute if people don’t think your contribution is valuable. Take the time and put in the effort to make your contributions really stellar. Once you’ve cemented yourself as a valuable contributor, just go ahead and contribute so much that you become the defacto documentation maintainer. Whenever anyone offers suggestions or corrections, always respond promptly and usefully. Pretty soon you’ll have a solid set of docs to show any potential employer. Always make use of spell checkers and grammar checkers. And read up on the rules of grammar yourself. No one will hire you if you make a lot of typos in communications during the hiring process. Write a book! There is always a demand for books on the latest versions of open source projects. Aim for a project that is far enough along to be useful, but still new enough to not have tons and tons of books already available. A lot of technical books are highly formulaic, and you can get tons of perfectly workable ideas from perusing the tables of contents of any of them. The best part is, if you don’t find a publisher, you can release the book in open source form and become a total folk hero! Here’s an example to get started: At the time of this writing, no big publisher carries a book about the Plover open source stenographic typing system. You could corner that market! So yeah. Those are some ideas for how to get started. Enjoy!

Most people are already technical writers but they are not even aware of it. For example, have you ever written a shopping list? Well, that is a legitimate piece of technical writing, even though at a very small scale. Have you ever written instructions how to get to a certain address? Have you solved a problem by offering a solution in writing? That’s what technical writers do all they long. Tech writing is all about offering solutions to technical problems and as a result changing the behavior of the reader in a positive productive manner. You can start technical writing by offering any kind of user manual, operational manual, or list at your place of business. This is the “sideways sliding” method that I’ve covered in great length at this article: How to Slide Sideways into Technical Writing | Technical Communication Center You can also transfer your existing set of skills to a different but still related job, as explained in this article: Career Stuck In Neutral? Move Sideways To Find A Related But Different Job | Technical Communication Center. One those related positions could very well be writing related. One thing you need to get rid of while you are at the beginning of your tech writing career is the assumption that all tech writing is high-tech writing. No, it’s not. There are dozens of low-tech writing opportunities that you should be aware of. Here are some ideas and resources that you might want to take advantage of when you are just starting on your career as a rookie tech writer: How to Find a Technical Writing Job – Some Ideas and Resources | Technical Communication Center "Hi-Tech" and "Low-Tech" Technical Writing for "Internal" vs. "External" Customers | Technical Communication Center Good luck!
